title: Kilnsey Crag Walking Route

images.title: Immanuel Giel [CC BY-SA 4.0 (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/4.0)], via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: View up to Kilnsey Crag. It was painted by J. M. W. Turner in 1816.

images.title: Kevin Rushton / Kilnsey, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Cottages of Kilnsey with the crag making a striking backdrop

images.title: Steve Partridge / Kilnsey Crag., via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Looking over from Scot Gate Lane above Conistone.

images.title: Humphrey Bolton / Old Hall and neighbouring houses, Mastiles Lane, Kilnsey, via Wikimedia Commons
images.caption: Old Hall and neighbouring houses, Mastiles Lane. Kilnsey Old Hall formed the main administrative centre for the management of wool for Fountains Abbey, which had extensive grazing land in the area. Some parts of the present Hall date back to this period, such as the gatehouse, most of which was probably built in the 14C. However most of the current hall was built in 1648 by Christopher Wade.

images.title: John S Turner / Stone Wall Junction above Kilnsey Crag
images.caption: Stone Wall Junction above Kilnsey Crag. The three walls shown here separate Low Ox Pasture on this side of the wall from High Ox Pasture on the left, and an unnamed pasture beyond the cross walls.

images.title: Kevin Rushton / Kilnsey
images.caption: View across the lakes of the Trout farm to the crag.

description: This circular walk visits a striking limestone cliff in the village of Kilnsey in Wharfedale. Start the walk near Conistone Bridge where there is a parking area. From here you can follow a footpath north west towards Scar Lathe and Kilnsey Crag. The route then takes you south west down Mastiles Lane which is an old Roman Road. It can be followed all the way to Malham Tarn with full details on the Mastiles Lane Route. This route, however, turns east along the How Gill. This will lead you across Kilnsey Park back to Conistone Bridge. The walk circles around the Kilnsey Park which has a number of attractions to visit. These include a trout farm and nature trails with with wildlife such as red squirrels, angora goats, alpacas and butterflies to look out for on the way. There's also the Café by the Lake where you can relax outside and enjoy fine views over the Yorkshire Dales while enjoying a good home cooked dish from the menu. The park and crag can be reached from nearby Grassington by following the Dales Way long distance walk from the town. See the Grassington to Conistone Walk for more details.

details.subtitle: Further Information and Other Local Ideas
details.content: Just to the south of the crag you'll find the Grass Wood Nature Reserve. There's some nice woodland trails, bluebells in spring and lots of wildlife to see here. The reserve is notable as one of the largest areas of broadleaved woodland in the Dales.
